And here we goes, another isekai combined with comedy anime. I would definitely say that 80% of travel to another world is a comedy as base. With the same combination of characters like: smart, dumb, justice, easily triggered and so on. And with not too much to expect, we have a random Tokyo dude who is full of social justice teleported into this land of mystery and got himself some juicy power and a harem.
Story - 7/10 :the story is actually not too shabby but easily expected, instead of the demon lord fighting, the antagonists are just a guy who tries to get more powerand conquer the world. the entire series are mostly illustrated in a light-hearted way, with a laugh or two in every episode even if in the last  couples where atmosphere got rather heavier. And personally i quite enjoyed that the story was set in a magic school, it was quite similar the magic school city in the Magi second season, where the entire school was counted as a country if i still remember correctly.


Art - 6/10: the art...was ok. maybe it is a tiny bit old fashioned where some character are drawn with overlarge eyes and with pretty weird MC haircut. but its just a opinion, because i know some people who likes this kind of art style better than the modern moe style which i cant really describe. however, on the other hand, everything else looked nice and clean, especially the landscapes and scenery when the protagonist were travelling.


Sound - 8/10: despite the comedy harem setting, the anime have some pretty fabulous OSTs. i cant remember where but when i heard that piano and violin duet, it was quite a moment. music can really decide if the scene is good or not, it decides if the scene is sad, joyful or excited. its like watching a depressing movie with random DJ song playing in the background while the protagonist is crying. it really makes a difference if the background music was chosen correctly.


Characters - 6/10: As i mentioned above, the characters were built lightly, with a classic personality but without originality. MC who are filled with justice and romance problems and side characters who are nothing but a laugh. i really cant say more about the characters, but you just need to watch it your self to know what i meant.


Overall, i gave it a 7/10 which i think is completely fine with it. not high enough to make it overrated but not low enough to cause objection. i would recommend to anyone who just want to watch some fantasy comedy for no other reason but just to waste some time and have a laugh.

Zero no Tsukaima is a very enjoyable anime series that was well worth the 
time to put into. It's one of those animes that had a lot to tell in 49 episodes, not rushed like some animes that only have 20+ episodes, sometimes leaving viewers in dismay of how short a good show could be. 
Zero no Tsukaima begins with the main female protagonist, Louise de La Valliere is the dunce of her class in Tristein Academy for magicians. Several years of unsuccessful attempt after attempt at casting spells, each resulting in violent explosions, have earned her the nickname of “Zero Louise” from her classmates.However, on the day that her class must summon a familiar each for themselves, Louise summons a commoner from another world: a young boy from Japan named Hiraga Saito, ultimately forming a bond and becomes the main male protagonist.


Visuals in general, including sound and artwork is somewhat not the best as I would anticipate. It's not Final Fantasy-ish beautiful with breathtaking quality, but I would say it's pretty decent. Not much to say since there's not much to be bashing about it.


Characters, creatively crafted for some, maybe a few were kinda cut-and-paste deal with some of them. I took great pleasure and joy in seeing Saito and Louise make names for themselves going from Zero's to Hero's both in their own rights. I can say I felt sad for some characters, especially Siesta because she is in a one sided love with Saito while Louise is in the way. But there are some redeemable characters like Guiche, Kirche, Tabitha, they're just the perfect supporting side players in the plot, sometimes shining in some scenes with some epic fights. As a honest guy, I liked Kirche a lot, especially because of her sexy looks and most of all, she's just perfect in the typical harem anime. Although they're not unique characters, their personalities are just humorous, especially how Saito is a pervert along with many other characters to sum it up. 


The replay value is not the best for some out there in my opinion. Some might not enjoy Harry Potter-esque shows like Zero no Tsukaima, but this romance comedy is just classic! I have found myself literally crying from laughter because of how funny some moments can be. Every episode makes me look foward to the next, leaving a feeling of satisfaction. I will admit some things in this anime can be predictable, but as a person who finished the entire series, this one is a keeper! 


I don't believe in perfection unless it's something like Final Fantasy VII or Beethoven's Symphony No. 9, but this anime is just very enjoyable. Perfect length to be an amazing series in 49 episodes, not rambling on like Naruto and Pokemon. And this is a very cute anime, especially on a person like me who has a penchant for romance series. This is fantasy based, so if those seek some more realistic ones, I would recommend ToraDora or Kaichou Maid-Sama, or even Angel Beats. Deep down, I really suggest you guys to give this one a chance, just once! This anime might be kinda awkwardly funny, maybe even cliched at moments, but the whole anime is very heartwarming and emotional! Some characters can be bland, one-dimensional, but the loving relationship between Louise and Saito is just beautiful in this romantic comedy!

The story is another cliché that we've seen a lot and this time it really is bad. The main story has as many plot holes as you can imagine (without taking into consideration how bad it is itself). The visual quality is really bad taking into consideration that it's not that old of an anime.
The character development is almost non existent and for the ones that do develop it is really bad. A lot of characters make an appearance without the proper relations to the story and that makes it almost idiotic.
Except for one case, everyone is either good or evil so you know whereit's going to end with anyone.\n
The music is really stupid and even though it goes with the "atmosphere" of the show it could have been a lot better (believe me, I'm being pretty generous).\n\n
Nevertheless, the reason I enjoyed his show despite all and every bad aspect is because of it sense of humor. Almost every episode had me laughing and thats the only reason I finished it.\n\n
So if you really don't mind those incredible bad aspects and you want to laugh a little then give it a chance.

Fair Warning:
A not-so-long mixed review about Zero no Tsukaima that is intended for people who have watched it. If you are a fan of the series that rated it as a 9/10 or something, I suggest that if you proceed on reading this, that you keep an open mind and try to think of my point of view.
So without further ado, let's begin.
Story: 7/10
So, first things first, a story about a boy, a 17 year old boy, who suddenly got Isekai'd while he was casually walking down the sidewalk like any normal human would do.  He was sumoned by this pink haired girl(loli) namedLouise, who also happens to be a Noble in their magical world, which is sort of a magical version of Europe, I've watched stuffs like this before. Anyway, now that Saito is summoned in this world, he must now live his life as a "familiar" of this pink haired girl called Louise. They sealed the "contract" using a kiss, how uncommon. Anyway things take off from there and basically, this boy, Saito, is treated like shit, less than human, like a dog even, repeatedly, basically almost everyday, how enticing right? Getting isekai'd as a mere "Peasant" no less. And who treats him like this you ask? No other than his "master" Pink-Haired Girl Le Blanc de La Vallière. I'm not gonna go any more deeper on this, basically, things happen, bad things from here and there, bad guys appear here and there, some other stuffs, and then they fuc-, erhm, fell in love with each other. What's more is that this was happening while there was a choice for him to go back to his normal life and quit being a slave, but nah man, he fell in "love". Then he gets treated like shit again.



Art: 6/10


I have watched a fair amount of anime from this time period,  the art is about what you'd expect, more or less. But if, maybe, just maybe, the budget was increased a little more, maybe it'd look better. Like Jigoku Shoujo, as far as I can remember, the art of this show was good. But the good points of this anime is that they try to show the fight scenes with much action as needed, and the animation doesn't get affected badly. So, I think it's good.


Sound: 7/10


I liked the OP and the ED. But I liked the OP better, it basically brings back memories, ah the nostalgia. Anyway, the sound effects were cool and all. The voice acting of the VA of Louise was the one that I liked the most, nothing less from Kugiyama Rie.



Character(s): 6/10


Oh man, this is where I get mixed feelings about, more on the negative side though. Especially with Le Blanc de La Vallière, AKA Louise the ZERO. I understand her situation, the fact that she's a noble and all, but boy, do she knows how to treat a human like shit. From being whip-happy (In her defense, there were some times were he deserved it, but too much is still too much) to making him sleep on the floor with only hay as a bedding, oh well, at least Saito isn't on a leash. Except for that one time. Also, this guy Saito, why doesn't he at least try and bring several things up with his "Master" about his treatment and all. Even after they became a "couple", he still gets treated like shit, and gets whipped. What was all that "character development" all about if these things happen again.


Enjoyment: 6/10


I can't say that I enjoyed this anime that much, but there are some parts that I enjoyed it, the rare cute parts of Louise being "dere" to Saito and the parts where he used things from the human world. But there's just too many negative things that I failed to ignore about the show. The biggest negative thing would be the character development with each other.


Overall: 7/10


This anime was on my mind for a long time, and I don't, in the slightest, regret watching it. It's not a waste of time like those anime that I've watched that I felt my brain rot and degrade over time just by watching it. I would recommend you to watch it if you could ignore the points that I pointed out above, other than that, I can say that the anime can be passed as good, if we weigh in all the good and bad things.


P.S. This Review is only exclusive to the FIRST SEASON (S1) and not, in any way related to the other seasons of the series. I plan on watching the others when I get the time.

That is all and thank you for reading.

Funny episodes but the overall storyline was too predictable.
I'm sure the creators intentions were for this anime to be light-hearted and straight forward. But the plot was too predictable for my taste. For the fantasy + magic genre, you'd generally expect something from the plot line. I put the series on hold at episode 9 because I got fed up with how obvious everything was. Overall, this is a good tsundere rom-com if you're not interested in a complicated storyline.

I began Zero no Tsukaima since it was labeled as a fantasy, but it quickly brought out the ecchi fan I had never known!
The story follows a chain of somewhat ridiculous coincidences that kept me laughing continually as the series went on. There was good drama and occasionally some fun adventurous/actiony pieces.
Characters:
Honestly, the characters did it for me in this series. You have Louise, who works very hard to keep up a good face and prove herself a worth mage, while continually failing. You can see how she takes out her feelings of shortcoming on Saito, whom she has a love hate relationship with. ThenSaito, who is just the unlucky guy who fell out of the sky into Tristain who is struggling with understanding the world he is now stuck in, and understand his feelings for his 'master', Louise. Then throw in Siesta, the good girl-better choice-adorable servant; Tabitha, the silent-studious-super power; Guiche, the womanizing-overly confidant; and of course Kirche, the always horny-boobs. Throw them all in a bag, shake it up and there's bound to be plenty of room for laughs.


Story:

The story, I'll admit, get loose at various times. There is always the sense of Saito trying to discover what his place is in the new world, and how to get back to his world. Then there is the ongoing battle of who Saito should be in love with along with his feeling that he should protect everyone regardless of their class. It takes the series a little while to develop a genuine evil-antagonist, which makes the overall story sail better (now that all the characters we like seem to have a common goal) but up until that point, I was willing to forgive that thanks to all the constant mini-fights between the characters.


Drama:

I loved the awkward feelings and uncertainty that were present in almost all the character relationships. I won't lie, I occasionally got mad a Saito when it seemed like he finally smoothed things out with Louise, only for him to fawn over someone else, but without his endless distractions, the fun and funny tension would have been gone.


Themes:

The show is a comedy-ecchi more than anything else, but there are a few deeper themes present in the show that make it further interesting. What role does pride play in how we live. Equality amongst people of different classes. How do we communicate love to the people that matter to us. Most of the themes appear only fleetingly, but they still make you think for that brief moment.


Overall, I really enjoyed the show. Zero no Tsukaima:

* delivers on the drama

* catches the watcher's curiosity (both in story and in characters)

* provides plenty of laughs


I would recommend it to anyone that enjoys a good, misguided love story.

Well, here comes Zero no Tsukaima, a harem-type anime with a tsundere for a main heroine. Another harem anime? Haven’t we had enough of this already? Yep, here’s another anime with a cliché characters, a subpar plot, and a ridiculous amount of fanservice. What? Seriously? Yes, seriously. Zero no Tsukaima is just another one of those terrible animes that people would consider crap. But why? Wasn’t  J.C. Staff the one who made this anime? I mean, J.C staff was pretty successful with Toradora! Wasn’t it? Well you see, Zero no Tsukaima is one of those “failures”, so to speak. It failed in almost everyaspect and is actually a terrible anime despite its huge fanbase. Why is that you ask? Well, I’ll give you the reasons why. Also, I would like you to know that this would be a review for the entire series and not just for this season. Now let’s move on to the review.


Story: The all-important story. Every anime needs a good, gripping story to entertain its viewers right? Well unfortunately, Zero no Tsukaima( which I will just abbreviate to ZnT for simplicity’s sake.) failed to deliver this all-important part of an anime. To tell you frankly, it had a great concept of what it was going to be. A simple summary of the story would be that Saito, a normal, everyday teenager was suddenly dragged into an unknown world and made a familiar by a magician nicknamed as Zero Louise, due to her lack of talent in using magic. It then turns out that the reason Louise can’t use magic efficiently Is because she only excels in a special, legendary type of magic which is void magic and that Saito is the knight of legend, Gandalfr. From that simple summary, one can guess that this would be an epic tale about two legends, trying to fulfill their destinies while encountering numerous hardships along the way, all while developing a romantic relationship between the two. Unfortunately though, the author just decided to go “Fuck that shit, who needs a decent plot when we got a tsundere main heroine, a pevert main hero, lots of tits and an entire harem at our disposal?” Yes, this is exactly what happened to ZnT. Instead of creating an intricate and enjoyable story and focusing on developing the plot, they just decided to give us a crap ton of fanservice, tits, a harem, and then proceeded to screw up the plot and rely on half-baked comedy and tits to try and hook its viewers. Although this would have worked if done correctly, even the comedic side was done half-baked.  One of the running gags in ZnT is that the MC, Saito, is an idiot who cannot seem to be able to hold in his boner and literally just drools of every boob he sees, and then proceeds to get dragged into the most awkward circumstances, and then gets beaten up by Louise. It was funny the first time but after seeing it in every single episode that had a scene wherein the MC interacts with a girl (which is like every fucking episode) it got old so much that it only served to annoy me every time it happens. So yeah, the comedy part was pretty horrid, but what exactly happened to the plot then? Well, as you would expect, the plot turned into a complete mush that only serves to further Saito’s harem(I would explain his harem later) and to create more opportunities for them to insert their stupid gag instead of actually developing the plot. I mean seriously, the plot had more plotholes than there are pimples on a boy going through puberty and had as much plot development as a porn flick. Yes, it’s that terrible. But seriously though, the series doesn’t even have a proper antagonist. In each season, a new antagonist is introduced, then they try to set up a scene where the MCs will fight the antagonist, only for the antagonist to be killed/go MIA in an instant, never to be seen or mentioned in the story ever again. So for short, not only doesn’t ZnT have a proper plot, it also doesn’t have a proper antagonist. The last thing that I would like to mention is about the lack of details and proper explanations in ZnT. Now, this is a common problem among a lot of animes, but ZnT just took it to new extremes. There are so many instances wherein inexplicably unbelievable things just happen. It seems that every time something bad happens, some incredible “coincidences” just happen for some reason. Like for example, in one instance, MC Saito is trapped in a room with only a brick wall separating him from his enemies and apparent death, but then guess what? MC Louise “accidentally” learns teleportation magic and teleports him and his friends to safety. Such ridiculous plot armor only exists in fairy tales, and in my opinion it is completely retarded to even try to incorporate them into anime. To sum it all up, I give it a 4/10, just because it is utterly ridiculous up to the point that they might as well add “the power of love” as one their plot armors. Oh wait, they already did, Stupid me.


Characters: As I’ve said before, ZnT is an anime focused on making scenarios wherein they could add ecchi and add more members to Saito’s harem. As such, one can expect that the characters are really bland. For one, there is ABSOLUTELY no character development in this anime, none whatsoever. I mean seriously, the main character Saito, a perverted, two-timing  guy who has as much sex appeal as Makoto from school days is still the same character he is four seasons after he appeared. Louise, a tsundere loli who only is Saito’s master and supposed “lover” is still the same stereotype anime girl who always gets into trouble and has to be saved by Saito. Then there’s Siesta, a typical maid who becomes a bitch after she falls in love Saito turns into a slutty bitch after who does absolutely nothing but press her boobs onto Saito in hopes of getting noticed after four seasons. After that, there’s Tabitha, your typical silent, mysterious girl stereotype that has as many expressions as Kristen Stewart who is still the same girl she is after four seasons, with the exception of being able to blush and sneaking into Saito’s bed while hoping to get laid or something(no really I’m serious). Then comes in Princess Henrietta, a stereotype girl who seems refined and stoic outside, but apparently has a habit of seducing our MC Saito whenever no one’s around. And finally, Tiffania, your typical air-headed girl with huge, f-cup boobs that always gets into “unfortunate” accidents with the MC is still the same air-headed girl with huge tits when the story ends. You see, there’s your problem; The supposed main characters are all bitches who could all have had a good, deep personality in them are all reduced into mere bitches who fight over Saito’s attention. Now, although there a lot of instances wherein their characters could’ve been fleshed out, like when their back story is explored in an arc, what the anime does instead is to make the girls seem all helpless and make Saito save them and as a result, they fall in love with him. Heck, I even think that some of the side characters have deeper personalities and are more fleshed out than the actual MC’s. I mean, Agnes and Colbert, two side characters had an ENTIRE arc dedicated to them just to reveal their back stories and were actually given a good introduction and excellent character development, all done with good execution but were just thrown away into the sidelines, only appearing thrice or four times in each season after their arc were finished. Now, there’s the problem. Instead of focusing their efforts on developing the main characters, they put their efforts in developing characters that would barely appear in the series while they could have given all that effort into fleshing out the main characters or even at least removing Saito’s inability to reject a girl’s advances especially since he’s already in a relationship. And top it all off, even the antagonist are just plain terrible and don’t stick around for long, as I’ve mentioned before. With all of those blunders, the only score I could give it is a 3/10, since pretty much every character are just about as interesting as one of those singing birthday cards; fun at first, but just damn annoying and noisy later on.


Animation: Pretty much the only good thing in this anime. Animation was smooth and shiny, just the way I like it. Although just like everything in this anime, there is always something lacking. The action scenes are so dull, it’s almost a bore to watch them. While fight scenes are supposed to be epic and adrenaline-inducing, the fight scenes in ZnT is just about as dull as watching someone else brush their teeth. It’s so slow that it almost look like it’s from a children’s cartoon show. So even with the animation, I can’t give it a perfect score due to the failure on the part of the animators, so instead I’ll just give it a 7/10 and be done with it.


Sound: There really isn’t much to say about the sound except that all of the BGMs were reused from the first season till the end and that the openings are pretty much sound just the same, only with different lyrics. 7/10


Enjoyment: Despite all of the negative comments I put up there, I actually enjoyed the first season. After that though, everything went downhill and my hopes of seeing a new masterpiece were completely shattered. But still though, I will take into consideration that I enjoyed ¼ of this anime so I guess giving it a 3/10 is good enough.


Overall: In conclusion, I would like to say that Zero no Tsukaima could’ve been a great anime. Unfortunately, all of that potential was wasted on a subpar plot, mediocre characters, and lame humor. To all those who are planning to watch this, only watch it if you are a die-hard tsundere fan or just watch the first season since the rest are crap. Overall I give it a 5/10.

Zero no Tsukaima is a fitting anime to watch if you are a lolicon masochist with a S&M fetish and your greatest dream in life is to have your face pressed under a girl's boots. If you're not, you might find it as an overly sadistic attempt at a slapstick comedy with an absurd romance, a bit of ecchi and the average boy getting a harem formula.
Generic Ikari Shinji knock-off Saito gets summoned into a fantasy world to serve as the familiar of a zero-talent loser mage, Louise. This fantasy world has a Middle Ages social setting with nobles, who can use magic, and peasants,who can't. And feudal kingdom setting to build up some background political drama to avert attention from this show's main theme. Anyways, Saito is instantly labeled a peasant and finds himself forced to become Louise's slave. And except for a few magic tricks he uses, thus getting Siesta (a maid, best girl) and Kirche (noble girl, slutty but decent compared to the female lead) to droll over him, and a few situations where he makes a difference, Saito is nothing but a loser with a strong Stockholm Syndrome who doesn't even want to return to Japan that much. As for Louise, I can only say that if most main girls are irritating with their tsundere antics, she is downright the worst female lead I have watched in a while. Louise is not even a tsundere, she is just a spoiled child too indoctrinated by her feudal status that she fails to even regard Saito as a human being, much less try to understand his circumstances, coming from a world where humans are equal in rights and chances. Either too hot or too cold; she lets him see her naked or even dress her up while she would wipe or even starve him at the slightest mistake. Good luck in getting some cheap generical prophecy and politics for a plot to cover that up.

I was only able to find Siesta slightly likeable out of all characters, even though she is more or less the typical Japanese maid (she is of Japanese origin through a great-grandfather, as to have that trope make more sense 😂).


I won't comment on the animation, considering this is a 2006 anime after all, as for the sound, I wonder if it was there in the first place.


So, you're a masochist and want an anime to fulfill your domination fetish? Suit your needs.

Zero no Tsukaima is an anime which doesn't do a good job at being a story driven anime of which would make it so much better.
My favorite thing about this anime is literally the art and even that isn't too great,but is merely alright.
Later on in the series you get introduced to a character that is added for comic relief basically and all it's lines make almost no sense and at times the words they says are things they shouldn't even know about and is one of if not the most annoying thing in this anime.
Overall I rate this anime a 5,because I didn't hateit..I merely think that it could've been much better and with a less flat love story.

I did not really like anime but with a nice drawing. Subject of a beautiful and natural, but 2 The topic of the season was a little different. The properties of the characters were more varied. There fore 2 I did not like season. As a result, was a good anime.

So Zero no Tsukaima is centered around Saito, the male protagonist, who was an ordinary teenage boy living in Japan before he was suddenly summoned by a student at Tristain Academy of Magic known as Louise, or as she was called in the beginning of the series by her classmates, Louise the Zero. 
Story
9/10
The story, I thought, was fine. It had plenty of comedy as well as romance, and I really liked the harem that Saito had with all the main female characters; albeit, some episodes had a lot of different genres coming in at once.
It was easy for me to follow along and overall,the story wasn't too jumble or anything.


Art/Animation

9/10


I liked the animation in Familiar of Zero, it's the kind that I prefer. The colors were appropriate and the backgrounds were to be expected in an fantasy type of anime, however, it made it all the better for me to really get into it.


Sound

10/10


I find the voices are well chosen (you can't go wrong with Kugimiya Rie voicing a tsundere character) and the op's and endings were awesome and are worth listening to. Also, I loved the music that would play in the background for certain scenes, they all really fitted and gave each scene the appropriate feel.


Character

8/10


I thought the character's were well developed and there were no sudden personality changes or anything, however, they were very original. I love how Louise never failed to give a tsundere moment, but at the same time, I like how she gave the impression of nobility (she should since she comes from a noble family)


Enjoyment

7/10


I enjoyed watching Zero no Tsukaima at first, but frankly, I got tired of the numerous ecchi scenes and how some episodes were just 'huh' There was a lot of comedy in it, but almost like there was too much in some cases. There was just enough romance for me, despite some of the romantic scenes being a bit cliché and too overused. 


I did start to lose interest after the first season, the episodes just seemed to (somewhat) drone on. Even though I wasn't as enthusiastic about watching past the first season, I did, and overall I did enjoy watching Zero no Tsukaima to the end. 


Overall


Albeit it with all that's been said, I think Zero no Tsukaima is overall a good anime to watch if you like ecchi, romance, comedy, harem, fantasy, batting with magic, and harry potter (no joke this anime will remind you of it) 


Despite a 9 overall rating, ZnT has remained one of my favorite animes and honestly, I would recommend it to anyone.

Zero no Tsukaima. One of the few unique animes i watched that let a "classic" impression off me. This anime is an example of an fantasy romance done right. As far as the story goes, as guess you could think of it as Harry Potter with the addition of familiars. Even though the story isnt original and isn't all that great, i guess its the world that get's introduced that leaves an good impression. It's a world of magic with wands, dragons, talking swords, lizards, giants, gods like gandalfr, It's a huge world. One of the reasons you get attracted to the anime isto find out and learn more about the world itsself and that drives you to keep on watching. The art isn't anything special. It's not bad, but i wouldn't say it's a masterpiece either. Lets just leave it as good. The sound is decent. I liked the second opening and the fourth opening stood out to me, but other than that, the music was ok. The characters are one of the strong points of this anime. Saito, the main character, gets transported from Tokyo, to the magic world. Having a lot to learn about the new world he's in, there leaves a lot of room for character development, which the animators do a decent job at. Louise, starts off as your typical tsundere who treats Saito as a dog. Character development is done well and she goes through a drastic change in the series. There are other noticeable  characters as well but lets just leave it at that for now\n
The romance of the series isnt the best but is still decent. The romance is cute, but it gets annoying how Louise becomes jeolous at every single girl that goes after Saito\n
The story,art, and enjoyment would be an 8,sound a 7, and character a 9, giving it an overall score of 8

Do you like tsundere girls? Do you like recycled jokes about boobs and the main character getting caught in misunderstandings and getting blown up in almost every episode? Well this is just a few of the things the first season of 'Zero no Tsukaima' has to offer... 
Story: 5/10
If you were preparing yourself to watch a pants dropping fantasy show with a stunning, jaw dropping plot line, you'll be fairly disappointed. To be honest, there's not much to talk about regarding the story. Throughout the season, there wasn't anything fascinating or amazing about the plot line. If anything, it was pretty cliched and predictable. Withregards to the ending, it really felt a little like deus ex machina and was kind of abrupt. 


Art: 6/10

There isn't much to talk about in the art department. There wasn't anything stunning or jaw dropping. The animation was decent and fluid, so there wasn't any eye sores throughout the season.


Sound: 6/10

In regards to sound, there was nothing memorable. None of the shows tracks were ear catching or stunning. However, the sounds did set the mood well and were used appropriately. (Additionally, in my opinion, the opening song wasn't that great...)


Character: 5/10

The characters were very generic and cliched. You have this tsundere girl named Louise that later develops feelings for Saito Hiraga. Then you have Saito, a generic, Japanese boy that takes the sword and saves the day, totally uninteresting. The side characters don't really do much but add to the stories humor and, occasionally, plot line. Despite there being character development, there wasn't a major impact. The character development felt like the show took a sticker and placed it over table. 


Enjoyment: 7/10

Despite the show being just a decent anime, I found myself enjoying this show a lot more then I thought I would. Something about this show made me want to watch more. Was it because of the shows harem? Maybe it was because of the shows 'misunderstanding' jokes? For me, I enjoyed it because of the pairing. Saito's and Louise's personalities are totally opposite which lead up to some humorous situations.


Overall: 6/10


This first season of the show is decent. The art, sound, and voice acting are all decent. All except for the story and the characters, they were pretty mediocre. 


HOWEVER, this is just the FIRST SEASON of the SHOW.

I highly recommend anyone that gives this show at least a 5 or 6 rating to watch the second season. Though, in my opinion, the second season doesn't fix all the points, it makes an attempt to correct them. And one of the HUGE fixes they make would be in the character development between Louise Françoise and Saito Hiraga. This is a huge point that made the second season of the show, Zero no Tsukaima: Futatsuki no Kishi, worth watching.

Saito... Louise.... Saito.... Louise...
The anime's genre itself really suits me. I am a huge fan of Fantasy, Magic, Romance, Adventure,  Harem and *cough* Ecchi *cough*. This is why I picked it up. And honestly, I don't know what makes me enjoy this anime, but I do.
The Saito and Louise relationship is a relationship that I really like, but at the same time really hate. If I were Saito, I wouldn't put up with being treated the way Louise is treating him. He still does, and to be fair, Saito isn't the perfect guy either, considering the harem going on and him not really understandingwhat Louise wants.


Nonetheless, the relationship progresses in a good way throughout the season, and even more in the next one. And there are really some touching moments throughout the season, which I must say I really enjoy.


Now, it comes to the plot/story. Here I must say I am not too impressed. Suddenly, a big problem erupts, and I am thinking: Ok, this will take some time to fix. 10 minutes later: Oh wow it's done already.

This is pretty much how much of this anime goes. And for some parts, it can be good, but for others, you wish you would see more epic fighting/magic then you already see. 


I can understand why this anime isn't liked by everyone. By some, it might be dull, boring and not entertaining, but for people like me, who really enjoys watching just a goodfeel anime that makes you go aww and yay, with a huge touch of fantasy/harem and some ecchi and some small touches of magic/fighting, I would recommend the anime.


It doesn't really live up to it's genres the way to be expected, but I am still watching episode after episode of this, mostly to see how the relationship of Saito and Louise is going to develop, and the story is at times also very exciting.


I will give this anime a 6 purely because I am enjoying it, but it's far from amazing.

If you are into BDSM this story is solid 10/10
Otherwise 2/10 because this is tsundere ad nauseum with emphasis on nauseum. It is hard to focus on other story when the main mistress constantly beats her slave and he gladly accepts a punishment. The story is too repetitive so I dropped it.
This story doesn't have characters, it has plot devices. So far everybody serves just one purpose what is convenient to story.
I found art average but boobs aren't drawn well, which is what matters in this story most. This show is about boobs, slave touching other girls boobs and mistress punishing him for that.
I donot recall soundtrack which makes it completely forgettable.

This was the biggest waste of my life, this is a show one can only enjoy if one is a super Masochist. I hated this shit, seriously one of the worst female leads ever. Totally one dimensional. Stay the hell away form this shit, trash anime. The worst anime I've watched by far and I've watched almost 160 and that's saying something. I don't get how an anime can be so shit. It's for your own good, stay the hell away. This is first review I've done and was motivated by a snap moment of pissed off state of mind that I let myself wastemy time on this pathetic anime,

While Zero no Tsukaima may seem like a cliche anime, it is very strong on all of his atributes.
The story while simple is catching and keeps you watching it, wanting more.
The art is pretty good considering the time the anime was made.
The soundtrack is simply amazing. It is always there to complement the scenes and give more emotion.

Aside all that, I can't give less then a 10 for the enjoyment, because even with its errors it stands out as an awesome experience.

*SPOILER FREE REVIEW*
I often wonder how Zero no Tsukaima received 4 seasons of production.
Story 3/10
The plot of the show wasn't terrible, but many ideas weren't original at all. There was concepts that was blatantly ripped off from other sources, which was pathetic. Furthermore, a good portion of the season was used displaying the characters as they ventured on their whimsical affairs, seemingly oblivious to the actual plot. The pacing was nice and consistent, though the plot twists were glaringly obvious and failed to captivate.
Art 7/10
The art was clean and the animation was smooth. Nothing that stood out though.
Sound 5/10
The OP and ED was completely forgettable.
Character2/10\n
This show had 2 main characters, following Louise and Saito. Both were terrible main characters. Saito is the epitome of bland. He had next to no redeemable qualities, nor interesting character traits. The only distinctive trait was that he was a pervert. Moving on, Louise is easily among the top most dislikable female leads. She is annoying, abrasive, arrogant, dogmatic and terribly temperamental. Yes, she is that bad.\n
 There are only two actual love interests, and the other girls had half-baked relationship development. Speaking of development, almost every character failed to have adequate depth. Zero no Tsukaima would be a stereotype heaven. They used every cliché in the book, causing the characters to give off a flat and uninteresting feel.\n\n
Enjoyment 2/10\n
Every moment was awfully predictable, and coupled with the illogicality of the characters, this anime really frustrated me.\n\n
Overall 4/10\n
Zero no Tsukaima was dreadful, and I would not recommend it.

well its OK until episode 11. it's no diamond in the rough but it's OK. but something happens in episode 11 that is simply unforgivable. to minamise spoilers basically the female mc is responsible for the death of an entire kingdom and the male MC who knew this would happen the entire time and tried to warn her reacts with " Oh Louise" im sorry but if someone kills literally millions of people from there own stupidity my reaction would be stronger no matter how much i loved them. also the rest of the show they just sweep it under the rug. WTF

This is a spoiler free review of the entire series of Zero no Tsukaima.
 when you watched (or watch) the first season you think "ok that was pretty good, ill give the rest of the series a try". Then season 2 comes around and you think "well once again pretty good, but feels a little repetitive". now season three rolls around and you like "alright how many times are you gonna do the same thing, this is still entertaining but getting ridiculous". But at this point dont make the same mistake i did and put off the last season. I cant really placemy finger on what exactly it was, maybe putting all the time into this anime  and seeing the light at the end of the tunnel. But of all the anime ive watch (which at this point is about 100) this is the most satisfying last six episodes i have ever seen. it makes you look back at the last three seasons and think "ok, that was definitely worth it, and really not that bad in the first place".  Most people who dont like this show cant see past the fan service or repetitive jokes, but if you can i promise it will be worth it.

I am going to review all 3 seasons of ZnT. IMO, S1>S3>S2.
Genres:
Fanservice:7 (More in S2)
Adventure:7 (Usually in second part of season)
Romance:4 (Here and there, reminds me of Yume de Aetara manga)
Magic: 5-6 (Depends on season, but magic is quite badly developed, esp for void magic)
Emotional/ Tearjerking moments: 8 (Usually have to do with Louise and Saito)
Season1:
Synopsis: High school boy gets summoned-> became "Louise the Zero"'s familiar->discover Saito's and Louise's power-> Princess' and Louise's history and related happenings->war-> Louise and Saito fight a war
Story:9
Very good, I remembered it is with little fanservice. Perhaps this is the starting, quite a lot of things started got resolved, andstory progression was really good. Emotional, adventurous and funny.\n
Note:About Saito's and Louise's relationship, it isn't until the end of S1 that they clearly admitted to each other. So in the end we have a nice, quite conclusive ending.\n
Story progression: Very good\n
Plot consistency: Very very good. (Only S1 has heavy emphasis on familiars) \n
Character:8\n
Main characters seem defined with character development. Saito, Louise, Tabitha and (the fire girl)\n
Overall:9\n\n
Season2:\n\n
Story:4\n
Mostly about Reconquista and a war, with some new characters and character development of some side characters.\n
Tabitha and Kirche rarely shows up.\n
Every1 became strange, the girls other than Louise were extremely attracted to Saito from ep1. Unexplained.\n
Louise begins "bipolar syndrome", sometimes sweet sometimes cruel.\n
Fanservice (violent type). Adventure. Uneasy atmosphere between Saito and Louise.\n
Story progression: First few episodes: Very rocky. Second half of S2: Strange.\n
Plot consistency: Good, but a lot of things not explained.\n
Character:5\n
Character development on Tabitha and Louise well done. A lot of old characters gone for many eps, some new ones go into focus. Hard to tell who are the main characters at times.\n
Overall:5\n\n
Season 3:\n
This is probably the most surreal out of the 3 seasons. \n
Story:8\n
Reconquista were not mentioned at all, although the leader escaped. No explanation.\n
Ring of Wisdom (?) also has no mention. New concepts were introduced but never explained.\n
New characters show up, old characters return, but very little familiars are present, most of the fights are with magic.\n
Fan-service is still quite abundant, albeit being smoother than S2's and more focused on ecchi.\n
Louise becomes more heavily "bipolarised", and shift of mood between her being bossy and proud vs insecure and humble becomes more unbearable. \n
Louise's and Saito's unstable relationship seem similar like those 2 in Yume de Aetara.\n
A lot of parts in the season are very abstract only giving a faint picture of the entire situation.\n
Second-half adventure features friendship and teamwork, gives shounen feel.\n
Fanservice (ecchi). Harem becomes larger. Incomplete feeling. Emotional Tabitha arc.\n
Story progression: Smooth, enjoyable\n
Plot consistency: Very weak, sometimes jumping here and there\n
Character:4\n
Other than introduction of new characters (which are usually big-breasted) and reappearance of old characters, not much done for character development.\n
Never-seen-characters sometimes take front stage, when we barely know them.\n
Nice portrayal of Louise being insecure about Saito but some things regarding her not explained.\n
Old Osmand only appeared once or smth in entire season.\n
Overall:7\n\n
[For all 3 seasons]\n
ZnT basically is about a couple with numerous difficulties due to harem and  their personalities. The problems they face makes the series interesting.\n
Somehow, the anime after the first season seems a bit diluted on content, and more concentrated on fan-service and a lighter atmosphere. Some crucial scenes were quickly moved over.\n\n
Story:6\n
Character:7\n\n
Art:8\n
Clear art. Advanced techniques used to make eyes look more sad etc. Facial expressions were good. Action scenes were excellent.\n\n
Sound:7\n
I love S1's OP and ED, and S3's OP. I like S2's OP but something seems to be missing. Sound effects were average, but voice acting was stellar, especially Louise's and Saito's, since they were in a lot of emotional scenes.\n\n
Enjoyment:8\n
S1 and S3 are great, I do not like S2 much. The fights, the comedy, the relationship problems between Saito and Louise were great. Friendship and loyalty are greatly treasured in ZnT.\n\n
Overall:7\n
Good 3-season series. Go read light novel, i'm quite sure it's much better than the anime in terms of plot for S2 onwards.\n
If you like the romance in this anime, try Yume de Aetara (manga).\n\n
PS.The official score is reflection of all 3 seasons.

art = meh. I'd give it a 4. Nothing special there
Characters: cliche and mainly made to pander into stereotypes. Let's not talk about how terrible the villains are. It felt like no one was even trying to be interesting. 
Story: most of it is dead obvious, but the way the real world mashes up with the magical world is interesting enough for me to give it a 5. Political intrigue does ensue, sidelined by cheesy plot, fan service and pointless shenanigans trying to make up for the bad characterisation. The romance feels forced for the most part. 
If you're looking for something to pass thetime while being brain dead, go for it. Perfect for little kids, I suppose?

Moe, Tsundere, S&M, Harem, Fan Service, having any of these elements makes the anime enjoyable. Having ALL of them in one series will make the anime UNFORGETTABLE.
I first watched the series when it first came out back in 2006. It was fun-filled, action-packed, full of fan services. There was never a moment of dullness with the antics of Saito and Louis.
However, looking at the overall plot, there were a lot of unanswered questions. Things felt rushed to the end. Luckily it was caught up with the sequels to shine more details into the overall story.
So if you are looking for a light-weight anime with plentyof laughters, Zero no Tsukaima is something you can start. Especially when it features Kugumiya Rie who voiced Shana from Shakugan no Shana

Magic is cool. Everyone loves magic. Having real magic, the stuff of fantasy is almost every child's dream.
Zero no Tsukaima is a rather hasty story that looks like it was at first originally to be a much longer first season as most of it is character development that suddenly, half way through, turns into everything is happening and then ending again all within one or two episodes leaving the finale rather lack lusting as you expected something more spectacular than was given. It opens a lot of question and leaves a lot of them unanswered as they go parading around the place, learning of manythings but never really question why.


Art is fairly par as nothing really stood out in its 13 episodes. colors and cell shading is basic stuff and even the scenery looks made of the same stuff not being something of awe which is rather lacklustering considering how much landscape is shown.


Music is subtle but decent. It's used to empower the scenes and convey the correct atmosphere, but not at a pace that makes it stand out which isn't a bad thing. However it is noted there is some stock sample music which is rather disappointing. Sounds are rather basic as reused multiple times which almost makes it seem this anime had a low budget to start with,


Characters left a lot to be desired. There is still much untold about the main characters and the only back story we've heard is of an MC's classmate. However the development between the Hero and Heroine is easily seen and steadily grows.


Enjoyment was so-so. It makes you laugh but it also makes you wish it would sometimes move on to something more meaningful or interesting. Don't be surprised if you reach the last episode of the season and wonder is that really all there was. It produced such a beautifully large potential story then cut it off at the hips with such a sudden ending

Before you start reading, I will first say that this review is an overall review to the whole series, not only Season 1 in particular.
Now onto the actual review:
It was a fun watch. It was interesting and funny enough to keep me going, but it's missing something special for me to say that it was magnificent. I have to say though that Season 2 'Zero no Tsukaima: Futaki no Kishi' was the best. It kept everything to a good balance and the ending was amazing. Only to be spoiled by its sequels. Season 4 'Zero no Tsukaima F' was a close second. It tried toreplicate all that was good of Season 2, but you can't expect the audience to fall for the same thing again. BUT what Season 4 had was a good and solid conclusion to the series.\n\n
TL;DR - Wouldn't recommend it, but a good watch nonetheless. Stopping after Season 2 would make the experience better.

Ah. Zero no Louise. That one will never get old.
This anime is a combination of:
- BDSM (Lots of Master/Slave stuff: whipping, humiliation etc)
- Magic & Mystery (Normal guy gets dragged into a magician world by force)
- Character Development (Hey its 4 seasons of this)
- Love & Harem (Lots of it, on a daily basis)
Those are the ones I remember. Anyway this anime is one of my favorites. Because of the sheer volume of episodes ranging through four seasons, the series is greatly developed and so is the story. The story is okay I guess, there are lot of shitty concepts like "Gandalf". Really author, youcouldn't come up with a better name so you snatched Gandalf from LOTR? Why? How does it even relate to this anime? The guy fights with a sword and doesn't yell "You shall not pass" anywhere. But anyway.\n\n
IMO the anime excels because of the sheer harem and love story development. The action is good as well, but not to the degree that I'd say its awesome. But the love & drama part? Its non-sense times ten with a scent of jealousy and lots of bdsm.\n\n
Louise is loud, dumb, proud and very very jealous. She tries to shackle and bind Saito in anyway possible. In every episode there is an angry scene of some kind where Saito is being beaten for the "Ero Inu" that he is and yelled upon. I'm sure he is sadomasochistic, otherwise there wouldn't be 4 seasons of this. Though as the anime matures more and more, so does the beating part of it as well. And because its a harem, with each season Saito's harem gets bigger and bigger but he never stops loving Louise and that's how the anime ends. IMO, this is a BDSM marriage mixed with vanilla standards. Idk if that makes sense, probably not.\n\n
I highly recommend this anime. It will make you laugh to tears, over and over.\n
But you will also bond with it and hook on it. Despite Louise being a time-bomb and Saito being a sadomasochistic pervert, you will like both of them. And if you don't, well its just not your cup of tea.\n

I watch this anime without any high hopes for it and thank god i didn't . Zero no Tsukaima Was an anime where it just seems that it have potential . Yet , that potential was replace with flaws . Even with flaws , i will say that Zero no Tsukaima did make me interest in its series . Hope the other is better .
Story:8
The story tells us about a girl that was bad at using magic who is the main heroine , Louise . She then tried to summon a sacred , beautiful and strong familiar which she obviously fail lol . What shesummon was an ordinary human who was the main protagonist , Saito . The story plot was fine . Nothing out of the ordinary .

The voice actor and actress here was good . Nothing that make me hate it or anything . Don't know why but the voice actress for Louise seems a bit like Shana from Shakugan no Shana . I could be wrong though . The OP and ED was nice . I like the ED better . It was relaxing .

The Beauty of This Anime
Let me just start from the top... hopefully all these emotions and thoughts racing in my mind will still be there by the time I'm done writing this but. I had not expected much from this show. This, what almost felt to be half-assed show with nothing in it. The only saving grace (that got me hooked) was the ecchi and the early on romance. That is when I had taken this anime a simple and cutesy one, that is what I had entailed for and I had accepted that. Of course... that's when I first started. Looking back now thatI have finished it, this show had absolutely been one of my favorites. How the jokeful beginning, although what back then I had thought to be (when i say beginning i literally mean the first episode) god awful had only contributed to the over all beauty of this anime. This is one of the few animes that I felt had wrapped up very nicely in the end. There was no"wait, can't there be an episode where they do this?" Everything had been fulfilled in this anime. The serious moments had only been made better as the jokeful ones made you realize all their hardships and good times together. Making the serious scenes (sigh sorry no specifics) a lot better. To be honest, I'm glad there were this many episodes, around 50. Because with this, you can almost feel the full impact of the entire anime. The love between Saito and Louise, their moments together, how they grew to be fond of each other and literally couldn't live without each other. You could feel the steady tension, the rising emotions and feelings. It had felt like you WERE saito, as each episode (throughout the entire series) had shown you a little bit of their lives. Each and every part, their fights, when they didn't like each other, when they missed each other, when they loved each other, and everything. This had all contributed to the overall feel of the anime, leaving you with this almost heart ache when the serious moments do come. As I'd like to point out clearly, you could feel the steadiness of the anime, like as if it never skipped from one episode to the next. You don't see them liking each other out of the blue for no reason, you reason with yourself how they got to like each other and it makes sense. It's not a surprise when you see them admit and say "i love you" because you could feel the steadiness and pacing. After finishing this anime.... I do believe I must call it a flower anime, or some corny stuff like that. An anime that, honestly, in the beginning you don't even know why you're still watching it. It seems to be kind of stupid. However, when you finally finish it, or the more you progress into it, the more you realize that every past action is simply meant to bring about the beauty in the next. It's a snowball effect, and that's why at the end you're left with a big giant freakin snowball in your heart and you are left in a room alone in the dark, where you're left to realize you just finished a beautiful heart-felt anime. (or maybe thats just me). Here's how I recommend this anime, it will only be beautiful and amazing if you watch this from start to finish. Every screentime ever scene every moment and every everything had feelings and emotions that would later bloom. If you are not going to watch this anime from start to finish. Don't, cus otherwise if you don't, it is the shittiest anime ever. However, from start to finish, at the end of the day, I could not help but add this as one of my favorites. (also, i had added this to an overall of 10 because, the story and character interactions i simply could not help but feel that this anime is worthy of a 10. Also, this is an overall review of the whole anime. I hope this will still help you in beginning a journey of beautiful wonders, just have the time to do so though. By the way, don't stop, it gets better ;)) 


P.S:

So that I'm not called a cheater or whatevs, this is also my review for the last season of this show. However, after re-reading that review I had felt it more potent to place into this review as to hopefully get more curious people to watch this slow but amazing show. Thank you! (sorry for my bad reviews by the way, I had recently started and I usually write these right after I finish the anime, while the thoughts and feelings are still flowing. However this USUALLY leaves me with a biased opinion. However, seeing how there is not much criticism I will be fair and write down what I had thought to be some bad things about the anime.)


The Downfalls, of This Beautiful Anime.


Although I wish I could say I loved this with all my heart, and trust me I do, I must try not to be biased and point out some flaws in this anime. As I had said before, this anime is very slow and almost makes you feel stupid for deciding to watch it. However, please find the joy in the echhi and the early on romance and you will feel bound to watch more, which is only making it better. This anime is more for the patient and the determined people who have a shit ton of time on their hand. Which leads me to another flaw. I had watched this anime in quick succession as I had decided to watch a long anime having too much time on my hands. This had left the snowball effect to be more effective since it had kept on rolling, if you do not have enough time on your hands, although I do not know if this anime will still be enjoyable. Be wary. Speaking of the early on romance, that is all its good for. The early on romance in the show (as i like to think of it, borderline ecchi but not quite), had saved the anime and hooked you into watching more. However, be wary, when the serious stuff happens and later you wish they would get along. It could quite possibly get on your nerves quite a bit. Also, somehow, I have no idea how, but that corny ass beginning had actually become a later charm of this anime. Corny being the whole magic school and the over dramatized everything. I'm not too big of a fan of magic when it comes to wands, especially when you use terms as "line magician." However, later in the anime as they developed the plot it turned out to be quite a charm of this show. 


UGH!

You have no idea how painful that was seeing how I love this show. I'm sorry, but please let me wrap this up on a good note XD.


Last Few Bits and Pieces


The story had dug deep into my soul almost. Although that is a little dramatic, how the anime had made a place within my heart by showing all the characters being fond over each other. Also how they grow on each other, I couldn't help but enjoy it and give them both a 10. To be fair I had wished to give the art a 9 but I had felt that would be too biased. Reason for this is that the kiss scenes, omg the kiss scenes, is what almost had been a major charm of this anime. On the art for that they had did amazing, however refraining from biased opinion I'll leave it at an 8. This being that the art did fall off slightly enough to bother me quite a bit. However I did enjoy the art very much of this show. The sound, at first, was horrible. But of course, they had saved the better for the later as later in the show it gets very nice and in fact you want to hear more. The corny playful music played in the beginning when everything was jokeful, being replayed when everything gets serious and tense. Almost like as if to you remind you of those good times, it is all very sad and I could not help but give a 9. okay then, that concludes this review, sorry for the long one but I had felt I needed to get everything out, enjoy! ^

This had so much potential. If this anime wasn't such a harem comedy type, it could have had such a good plot. I know i shouldn't be expecting anything too great, but honestly, this could have been really cool. If it incorporated a dramatic or more intense serious mood, it may have been really good.
 What I DID like about it was the fact that he can use any earth weapon, especially the Zero (history buff). well, its decent for being a harem, ecchi, comedy anime, but it could have had a better story. If it took itself a tad more seriously like Chivalry ofa Failed Knight did (which was a pleasant surprise), it would be a 9/10\n\n
Overall, this is a 5/10 for me, not that great. I'm on the 2nd season while writing this, so hopefully it gets better.

On the rating system, 4 is considered decent. This is not the case for me. 4, to me, is something I want to destroy. I can respect you if you liked it but I personally want to end its existence.
So... Dear Zero no Tsukaima, please stop existing.
Story - 
I'll be honest, the idea of a modern guy being taken to a fantasy world of magic is a good idea. However, its done by nearly everyone in some way. For example, X person comes in and makes Y's life more interesting. That is basically what this is however you are at risk of causing a hellof a lot more plot holes this way.


Fortunately, Saito's origin isn't immediately forgotten about and is actually quite integral to the 'plot'. I use ' ' because there are only really a few episodes that actually have relevant information in. The rest of the episodes are just a poor excuse for one-liners, repeated jokes and boobs. Even without these episodes, the plot is actually pretty corny and has no real direction or pacing. I mean..... one of the core characters get introduced 4 episodes before the end and only appears in 2 of them for 5 minutes each.


This is just one example of how some of the more interesting and core elements of the show are neglected in favor of cheap jokes and a mediocre love triangle with no real importance or comedic value.



Art and Sound  - 


I don't remember anything about the sound because it was so average. On top of that, there was really nothing that I can say about the art besides that it matched the quality of the show overall.


It may not have been terrible but if you have nothing good to present with it then you can only expect a rating as good as what you're dependent on.



Character -


Everyone in this show was so stereotypical of a high-school anime. You got the righteous new guy, the underappreciated girl, the busty bimbo, the big mouth romeo and a few perverts here and there. The show knows that these people are cut and paste and uses that to try to present them in an ironic manor, however, they get caught on a nail halfway through and end up making them look even more standard and plain then they would if they tried to take the whole thing seriously.


Everything from the individual, the relationships and the love triangle are absolutely mediocre and cringe worthy. Just.... poor.....


As a fairness to this anime though, the VA for Saito in the dub did a pretty good job for his first role. Although that appears to be a matter of debete



Enjoyment  - 


It didn't happen so I can't say anything about it.



Conclusions -

The Zero no Tsukaima anime is very mediocre although some aspects of the anime is somewhat redeemable:
The story is "ok" not at all great.
The two main characters are fair they do have some good chemistry together
The supporting cast are entertaining.

The story is average at best, this is because of the substance it gives like what's the motivation of the character main and the sub character. The 2 main character are somewhat common today, but something stands-out in the focus of the story instead of the Male protagonist, Saito, being the main focus it wasthe Female protagonist, Louise, who stands-out more. There chemistry is  fair it's not at all bad and sometimes cute. The Sub character are good some better. Siesta is supposed to be an another love rival of Louise but it doesn't really feel like it. Saito doesn't really care that much of her, there was this one episode where Saito tried to save Siesta but it was overshadowed with how much of a douche bag are the Nobles not focusing on Siesta but more on focusing the Nobles greediness. Siesta overall is really not that significant in this series.

Alot of people think that this anime is to far based on Harry Potter, but really, the fact that magicians are involved is just about the ONLY thing based on HP. 
The first few episodes are just some "Fun get used to the characters" episodes, so don't judge it the first few. 
(This all takes place in a different realm then ours)
It's about Louise, she attend a Magic School, except she ALWAYS end up blowing up something up when using her wand. Always. One day, as a school project, she is to summon a familiar (Magician's partner/+servants), everyone else summons awesome familiars, while Louise summonsa human, from another realm (our realm), he is just a normal japanese kid (voiced by the same guy who did Yuji in shakugan no shana :OH SNAP) but he is forced to be her servant. It's pretty hilarious. After the first goof-off episodes, things get serious. People are put in danger, we discover family problems with some characters, so on and so forth. It's a very good series. It's kind of like a Shakugan no Shana, but 5x's less serious. Also, tagging it as "Adventure" fits PERFECTLY.\n\n
I hope I was helpful, if I wasn't...sorry XD\n\n
Wish you the best on your Anime Quest\n

I must say I rather liked it. For something that is apart of one of my favorite genres in anime, I must say I really approve of this anime. 
Do not let the synophsis fool you. Yes I at first didn't think it was all that interesting but when I started to watch it (because of my irisistable urge of wizardy.. Curse you Harry Potter!) I became slightly interested, and by the second episode I was more interested in it.
I haven't read the manga yet, I plan to but I cannot at this time give you the difference between the stories. I can tell youis that it was slow at first but was still building. Which is good. Louise and Saito's like for each other is building.. and if you know that some anime just rush into the romance, this does not.. even though it is a short series consisting of only 13 episodes. 


This--if anything--is more like a prologue to the story itself. I must say the story has captured my interest enough to where I want to watch the sequel. This anime has the potential to be one of the best. 


The art was very good as well, a bit girlish, but very good none the less. I enjoyed the scenary, the effects of the magic, etc. The characters expressions where very well captured. I don't have much to say for the art other than that I really liked it more so than most animes. 


And here is where it defaults. The sound. 


The opening and ending were good, though I sometimes skipped the ending song because I didn't enjoy listening to it all that much. It was good, but could have been better. The opening was better suited to the anime itself.


The voice actors for english.. Well, I must say it was a miracle that it wasn't bad to the point where I wanted to choke FUNimation. In other words it is watchable, but do expect to become annoyed. Some of the voice cast didn't seem to fit the role, like Saito, but some fitted nicely. And this is saying much seeing as FUNimation always seems to have a way to mess up the casting. So yes it was nicely done. A fair six I say. 


Hey, just because I said it was watchable and the opening and ending were good doesn't mean I am going to give it a higher rating. Six is fair enough considering I watched the whole thing in english. 


Characters now. I am finally glad to say that I haven't seen any Mary-sue qualities yet. Louise and Saito's relationship is at a slow building process, even if the anime--as I said--is short. Some of the other characters as well where enjoyable as well.. Though I must say that they really didn't need to give one so much sex appeal and have that needy tone, one with such pride.. 'blah'.. They were still good and helped the story progress.


My enjoyment of this was great. I really enjoyed the humor, story, character, sound could have been better, the science behind it.. Almost everything. I would say if you like Harry Potter or just into the whole magic world, this is a fun watch.. but do expect to become slightly annoyed somewhat.


Overall, it is a very good anime. Some minor flaws now and again, but it was a nice prologue to the rest of the series.

I'll admit when I came across this anime at first, I didn't like the theme with the whole medieval time and witches. But I gave it a chance, and it had made me come to realize it was just plain amazing. Some episodes had me in tears because of how much it touched me. The romance was just at the right amount. They were adorable. The only thing that bothered me while watching this anime was how many annoying side characters there were, and how many typical girls fell for the main male protagonist. I'm the type of person who enjoys all types of anime, i just got done watching two series that really went into depth and involved a lot of twists, turns, and mystery in the plots so I was really in need of an anime that i could sit back, watch, and just enjoy the characters and this was it. The truth is that I entered this series just for some laughs, those sexual mishap moments, and to be taken away and feel like I was in the story, what I got was all that but I discovered this story was given a plot as well,there were those moments where lose strings are suddenly pulled together, those shocking moments of trechary, and then those moments that make you fall over laughing due to the pure comedy of the situation. What's the anime about:
There is a world where there are two kinds of people magic users Aristocrats) and non magic users (Pleibeians) The anime sets play in a magic school for the aristocrats. In that school there is a girl who gets called 'Zero' because of her 0 success rate on spells. Anyway the second years which she is too has to summon a kind of companion, which is called 'familiar'. She summons the worst possible she thinks, a human. The human has to take care of the mage and they will have fun and 'romantic' stuff.
What can I expect:
Basically you could expect a greatbasic story and a bad progressive work.


we can say that events taking place are done OK, but lacking in one specific thing: Which is reappearance of events. For example: you get a world saving ring and must wear it at all times and the next episodes it gets ignored, Because that specific thing gets done a lot and I hated that a lot.


Also you can expect a lot of fan service and overdone situations.


Story:


The story of this anime is basically an introducement to the surrounding theme, which is magic and of course fantasy, and a small explainment of characters. The story is OK, but I hoped some more. The pros are in the work of knowledge, they make it so we know the same amount of info as the characters in the anime. That's done well and I got more interested in the anime. Tough the cons is really the fan-serviced environment of the anime, it's just annoying sometimes.


Art&Sound:


The art and sound are even better then animes that come out these days, and that in 2006, Really good from them.


The art is less detailed, but fine, and the sound is amazing. Nothing to complain.


Characters:


The characters feel really kind of off, the main characters are done good, but one episode characters just lack some stuff. Besides that every character has fan service and are predictable. I feel that the character design lacked, but was okay.


Enjoyment:


This anime is so much fun to watch I laughed a lot and felt with the characters when something bad happened. From random events to laughable people the comedy part was done really good, But the romance lacked, a lot! There wasn't really romance in this anime just romantic ecchi. If you are here for the romance I wouldn't recommend it. Besides the romance part the ecchi is good and feels attractive I guess. The action in this anime is bad just horrible. But there isn't too much in it.


Overall:


A hilarious anime with a lot of fan service and great art&sound.


Recommended for echhi and comedy lovers.

This review is for all 4 seasons of Zero no tsukaima, as in my opinion is not much of a difference between them.
Story - 
The story is well done, although it is nothing super complex and it's not the main focus of the show anyway. It's easy to follow, consistent and yet not totally plain.
Art, Sound, Design - 
Nothing special to say here, you can see the graphical style in trailers or pictures, and the animation in normal scenes as well as in fights is well done.
Overall - 
The main aspect of the show is the two main characters trying to get along, as oneof them is an aristocrate in a world of magic, while the other one is her familiar, brought to her from the "normal" world. So a master-slave relationship (not in a perverted manner) between two people of completely different backgrounds, and furthermore even being from two different worlds.\n\n
Over the 49 episodes from all 4 seasons they build up quite the cute romance, with many romantic, tragic and funny dialogues / scenes between them. What I didn't like was that both characters are extremely dense when it comes to talking about their feelings, and her being enormously jealous (while he gives her every right to be so in the beginning). That results in nearly no progress in their relationship during the second and third season, as basically every couple scene is followed by a fight again. \n\n
So if you solely watch it for the romance, you might want to skip at least parts of the episodes of seasons 2 and 3 as it will possibly feel dragged out, the main progress happens in seasons 1 and 4. It is still worth it in my opinion, the ending was awesome and in between you might even be forced to shed a tear or two (depending on how sensible you are of course ;) ).\n\n
So in short, the reason for my 8/10 is that it becomes a bit repetitive in the middle, with both characters constantly going back and forth with arguing and loving. But that's the only thing I have to criticise about it.

I must admit, I'm thoroughly surprised at how good this was.
Zero no Tsukaima! An anime about magic & alternate universes. The anime is about a boy named Saito who is magically teleported to another universe where things aren't what he's accustomed to. He later finds out that he's been transported to a world called "Halkeginia" and that he's become a "familiar." Really, the story isn't too special or anything, but given the year this anime was released, I'd say they did a great job at making a "unique" anime for the time.  However, just because this anime is old, doesn't mean that it doesn'tfollow the same types of cliches that we have seen many times before. 


The art and sound are both quite good too! Almost has a similar look to Toradora! in some ways. The OP is pretty catchy, too. As well as the entire OST!


Anyways, let me just say this right off the bat: if you don't like the tsundere type, please don't even watch this. I've read too many reviews about the main girl character and how she's so obnoxious or whatnot. But aside from that, the characters in general, are pretty good. I really should mention that there are definitely some generic characters here, some that kinda just have absolutely no "character" to them at all: IE, most, if not all the villains and their motives are just really plain. But since they're not entirely the focus of the plot here, I'd say the main characters really make up for that.


Overall I have to say, I'm impressed. I really had no expectations in the beginning, and I really expected this anime to be just "alright." Each episode really pulls you in wanting more from the next. And while there *really* isn't anything different about this anime, I personally had a fun time watching it. I reccomend you give this anime a watch only if you don't mind some bland characters along the way. Trust me, it's pretty fun.

This series was difficult for me to get through. This was recommended to me since I enjoy fantasy and a good romance series. I figured this was right up my alley. Boy was I wrong.
I was never a big fan of the tsundere-type characters, though it hasn't ruined a show for me, at least not until this series. Louise is one of the worst main characters that I've seen. Her male counterpart is bound to her, so she literally treats him like an abused dog. I'd be fine with this series if the characters matured over time, but the lack of "dere" from Louise justmakes her seem like a spoiled bully all throughout. For me, a perfect example of tsundere done right, would have to be Taiga in Toradora! She's all "tsun" at the beginning but grows softer/kinder as the series progresses, unlike Louise in this series.


Saito is no better. He saves her time and time again, but the dude lacks a spine when it comes to her. He allows her to beat him, he flirts with other girls, even though he knows that it will result in further beatings. Then he comes back to her with hearts in his eyes because he really cares for her. Other women are practically throwing themselves at him, yet he's head-over-heels in love with the bully that has trust issues.


Writing this out, it sounds more like a love story between a sadist and a masochist, which isn't for me. I just don't understand this sort of relationship.
